section.title: Prerequisites
section.para: Gradle requires a Java JDK and a JAVA_HOME environment variable pointing to the JDK. Gradle ships with its own Groovy library. Therefore no Groovy needs to be installed. Any existing Groovy installation is ignored by Gradle. The standard Gradle distribution require a JDK 1.5 or higher. Beginning with 0.3 we also provide a distinct JDK 1.4 compatible distribution.

section.title: Unpacking
section.para: The Gradle distribution comes only as zip. Additional to the binaries it is shipped with:

listitem.para: The binary sources (If you want to build Gradle you need to download the source distribution or checkout the sources from the source repository)

note.title: For Un*x users
note.para: You need a GNU compatible tool to unzip Gradle, if you want the file permissions to be properly set. We mention this as some zip front ends for Mac OS X don't restore the file permissions properly.

section.title: Environment variables
section.para: For running Gradle, the GRADLE_HOME environment variable needs to point to the root directory of your Gradle installation. Then add GRADLE_HOME/bin to your path.

section.title: Running and testing your installation
section.para: You run Gradle via the gradle command. To check if Gradle is properly installed just type gradle -v and you should get an output like:
section.programlisting:
---------------------------------------- Gradle 0.5.2 ----------------------------------------
Gradle buildtime: Thursday, January 8, 2009 10:23:01 PM CET Groovy: 1.5.6 Ant: Apache Ant version 1.7.0 compiled on December 13 2006 Ivy: 2.0.0-rc2 Java: 1.5.0_16 JVM: 1.5.0_16-133 JVM Vendor: Apple Inc. OS Name: Mac OS X

section.title: JVM Options
section.para: JVM options for running Gradle can be set by either defining an environment variable GRADLE_OPTS, or by setting the GRADLE_OPTS variable at the beginning of the gradle script.

section.title: Getting Help
section.para: You might check the userguide at GRADLE_HOME/docs/userguide/userguide.html. Typing gradle -h prints the command line help. Typing gradle -t shows all the tasks of a Gradle build.
